awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Transport Processes Affecting High-Energy Solar Energetic Particles Observed at Earth
awd_abstract_narration:
The Sun occasionally has massive eruptions that are capable of producing very high-energy particulate radiation.  These "solar cosmic rays" are created near the Sun, move through space between the Sun and Earth, and impinge on the Earth's upper atmosphere.  These particles pose a significant radiation hazard to humans in space, space hardware, and may even increase the radiation dosage received by airline crews.  The project teams can measure these particles using Earth-based detectors, known as neutron monitors, which are also used to measure galactic cosmic rays that come from outside our solar system.  Relating the size of any given solar storm -- i.e. the amount of energy released or how big it is, etc. -- to the intensity of the particles at Earth requires a careful and thorough study of how these particles move between the Sun and the Earth.  This "transport" is not uniform, and the resulting intensity at Earth depends on a number of factors, such as the nature of the magnetic field in space, that must be studied carefully.  That is what this three-year collaborative project is about, and it involves numerical modeling and comparing those modeling results with neutron monitor data.  The research studies address the general problem of understanding the space radiation environment and space weather especially that from solar flares, leading to more accurate future predictions.

This three-year collaborative project will investigate the role of interplanetary transport, in the form of pitch-angle scattering, cross-field diffusion, field-line meandering, and drifts, of high-energy solar particles in affecting the observed intensity and direction at Earth, seen as ground-level enhancements (GLE) in Earth's neutron monitors.  GLE events can often show very unusual profiles in terms of the observed intensity versus time and anisotropy.  Some show an abrupt, short-lived peak followed by a gradual decay, or even re-enhancement, followed by a decay.  The observed profiles provide important information about the nature of the particle transport from the Sun to the Earth, which has not been fully explored.  The project teams will perform a large number of numerical simulations which solve the equations of motion of a large number of individual particles moving in a set of kinematically specified interplanetary magnetic fields.  In parallel, they will also analyze the neutron monitor data set for GLE events, characterizing the intensity versus time at various stations.  Through collaboration, they will identify events to compare directly with the numerical simulations.  The numerical simulations will consider a number of important new effects which have not yet been completely explored, including the heliospheric current sheet, which likely has a profound effect on ~GeV-energy particles.  In addition, the researchers will consider the importance of field-line meandering, which can lead to a non-uniform intensity of high-energy solar particles seen at Earth.  The research and EPO agenda of this project supports the Strategic Goals of the AGS Division in discovery, learning, diversity, and interdisciplinary research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Collaborative Research: Transport Processes Affecting High-Energy Solar Energetic Particles Observed at Earth

This grant is a collaboration between the University of New Hampshire and the University of Arizona.  In particular, the collaboration is between the instrumental program at UNH and the theory program at UA.  Both aspects are necessary for a scientifically productive neutron monitor program.

The central instrument that provides the data for theorists to digest is the neutron monitor.  The neutrons that are detected are themselves not the subatomic particles of interest.  They are, instead, byproducts of cosmic-ray interactions with Earth’s atmosphere.  The neutron detection rate is measured and constitutes a direct measure of the frequency of cosmic-ray interactions and thus the intensity of the cosmic-ray field surrounding the Earth.  Neutron monitors are large ground based instruments, placed around the globe and they are sensitive to the most energetic cosmic rays.  Lower energy cosmic rays are sensed by spacecraft instruments.  Both high and low energy cosmic rays are important for our understanding of cosmic rays and the workings of the solar system.

The cosmic rays in question are produced elsewhere in the galaxy.  After traveling thousand of light years, they are significantly affected by the activity of the Sun once they enter our neighborhood.  There are many processes that modulate the cosmic-ray intensity and those processes respond to solar disturbances both large and small, fast and slow.  Measurements of the modulation effects are the data we need to understand the behavior of the medium between the Sun and us. 

Another source of cosmic rays is the Sun itself.  At the energies measured with neutron monitors, these cosmic-ray events are infrequent, but can have profound impacts on spacecraft, astronauts, and high flying aircraft, especially for flights over the poles or high latitudes.

The neutron instruments themselves are relatively inexpensive to maintain.  This is good, because very long term measurements of the neutron count rate are critical to trace the intensity of solar activity over several 11-year solar cycles.  These long term measurements rely heavily on a subset of the world-wide network.  Two such stations are located on the summit of Mount Washington in New Hampshire and at Climax Colorado.  The continuity of these measurements is an important feature.  However, that continuity has been interrupted at a few junctures and should be minimized.

The station on Mount Washington is housed in a wooden building, built to withstand the severe weather on the summit.  However, the constant assault by the snow, ice and hurricane-force winds takes its toll.  Around 2007, the building almost failed catastrophically, forcing us to temporarily de-commission the instrument, store it and find the resources to rebuild it.  This came a few years later in the form of a student project by the Berlin High School Technology program.  All the while, the Mount Washington Observatory charged rent.  It is a non-profit entity and they provide various services for us, including electricity and emergency support on top of our occupancy expenses.  A significant fraction of the grant went in this direction and the personnel necessary to effect the repairs.  The personnel included our engineer and a graduate student (who will be using the data for his PhD thesis).  This time also provided an opportunity to upgrade the electronics system.

Any work on the summit is restricted to the summer months.  The extreme weather precludes anything but emergency services at other times, but through it all, the monitor is intact and is now collecting data.

The other unexpected expenditure occurred at the Leadville Colorado site.  The Leadville station exists as a replacement for the Climax station that had to be abandoned due to a secession of funding in the 2000s.  The Leadville station expenses were assumed by our industrial partner at the time, IBM.  However, IBM sold that division to Global Foundries, who became our new industrial partner.  However, that partnership did not last, because Global Foundries decided to get out of the cosmic-ray/microelectronics investigation business.  This left us alone to pick up the operations costs and relocation of the instrument to the other side of Leadville in a storage facility that charges rent.

These two major redirections of our activity consumed our resources.  Our recorded data volume is much lass than what we planned, but the instruments are intact and operating, all necessary for providing researchers and the space weather community a continuous stream of data, albeit with a few interruptions.
